awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Catalytic Membrane Reactor for Commercial Production of Biomass-Derived Fuel and Fuel Additives
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project is to develop an alternative source of renewable energy and chemicals to help address the worldwide increasing demands for energy. It will provide a new and abundant source of renewable energy and chemical intermediates with long-term effects. Development of these platform chemicals from renewable cheaper resources, such as waste crops, can impact the economics of the chemical industry by leveraging new starting materials. Technology breakthroughs from this work will enable broader adoption of bio-based products.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology for production of platform chemicals using a catalytic membrane reactor. The technology focuses on simultaneous catalytic hydrolysis, dehydration, and rehydration of renewable biomass to bio-based platform chemicals and biofuels. The feed used in this technology is lignocellulosic biomass instead of conventional monomers as starting materials accounting for significant feedstock cost reduction. The competitive thermochemical and enzyme-based technology have major disadvantages such as high energy demand, high cost of enzymes, and involves multiple complex processing steps. Further, comparative chemical conversion processes use corrosive acids or expensive ionic liquids which are unacceptable with present day industrial norms. The technology uses non-toxic, inexpensive, robust, and easily regenerable enzyme-mimicked catalyst efficiently catalyzes multiple reactions with high desired product yield using carefully selected solvent system. Furthermore, the proposed technology is intensified using membrane process that helps in simultaneous catalysis and separation of the products shifting the thermodynamic equilibrium preventing product decomposition. Previous fundamental research has shown that the proposed catalytic membrane can convert both cellulose and hemicellulose part of the biomass, which opens the possibility of future developments that focus on production of multiple other products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
NSF I Corps funding enabled the Catalyst by Design Team to conduct customer discovery in order to understand the commercial potential of the  patented technology that has been developed through prior NSF funding. Previous NSF funding has led to the issuance of 4 patents and three research papers. However the commercial viability as well as societal need for this technology was unknown. The technology provides a new way to convert waste biomass such as agricultural residues, food waste and municipal waste into chemicals that could be used to produce fuels and bio based products.

The intellectual merit of the work conducted with NSF funding lies in the customer discovery conducted by the I Corps team. Through over 100 customer interviews the I Corps team determined that there is a market need for this technology. The I Corps team further determined that the technology could be used to help current corn to ethanol facilities, of which there are over 200 in the US,  convert corn fiber to sugars. Corn fiber is a byproduct of  these corn to ethanol plants.  The sugars could then be converted using their existing manufacturing process to ethanol, thus increasing their ethanol yield at very little additional cost. The new knowledge gained enabled the I Corps team to form a new startup company, SIEV Technologies which is working to commercialize the technology.

The boarder impacts of this work focus on environmental sustainability. Development of more sustainable technologies is of tremendous importance. Development of renewable resources for production of transportation fuels is of significant societal impact. The current technology could offer a cost effective way to produce ethanol from waste biomass for use as a transportation fuel. Further production of ethanol from corn fiber, a low value by product in the corn to ethanol production process, will enable current corn to ethanol plants by maximizing their ethanol yield. This will help these facilities remain economically viable as ethanol is a commodity product that shows significant price fluctuation.


Last Modified: 06/01/2022
Modified by: Ranil Wickramasinghe
